fields.title: UNIT A - About
fields.content: UNIT A is a 7000sqft. Art space that houses and preserves the works by Internationally renowned painter and New York City native Marcus Jansen that stores works from his early career in 1997 until 2013. Mr. Jansen recently recieved the Arte Laguna art Prize 2013 in Venice Italy and has been given the "Key to the City"  by Mayor Randy Henderson personally the year prior. UNIT A is located in sunny Fort Myers, the home of the late Robert Rauschenberg and Roy Lichtenstein as well as other World renowned artists who have resided and still reside in the region. UNIT A has partners in Europe, Asia and the United States.

fields.title: UNIT A - Biography
fields.content:
Marcus Jansen, born 1968 in Manhattan, NY, lives and works in Southwest Florida.

Former Museum Director Jerome A. Donson  selected by the United States State Department and the United States Information Agency, responsible for traveling exhibitions at the Museum of Modern Art (MOMA) and the Guggenheim Museum in New York curated international exhibitions including the directorship of the American Vanguard Exhibitions in Europe 1961. Donson collaborated closely with action painters Robert Rauschenberg, Johns, Franz Kline, Jackson Pollock and Willem de Kooning in the 1960's. He notes Jansen's work as "reminiscent of the Ash-can School" referring to Jansen as "the innovator of modern expressionism" in Jansen's first published book in 2005.

Jansen explores today's human condition through a series of gritty paintings that expose the harsh nature of contemporary life, many of which reflect the changes taking place in today's society. Jansen's work is a mix of abstract expressionism, graffiti and pop that results in a depiction of often political and soclially influenced provoking imagery commenting on world events and a transforming world order.

At age 44, Jansen's work has appeared in numerous International and national Museum exhibitions including the recent "Anonymous" exhibition at The PERMM Museum of Contemporary Art curated by Marat Guelman and the "All Florida" Exhibition at the Boca Raton Museum of Art curated by Mark Scala. Jansen has been noted in publications by Dan Cameron, (Founder of US Biennial Inc.) in New American Paintings as well as published in Art Pulse, Art News, Art in America, The Boston Globe and The New York Times. His work has shown at International Art Fairs such as Art Chicago, Dallas Art Fair, during Art Basel Miami Beach, Art Hamptons and  at the LA Art Show. Over the last  decade.Jansen's Museum collections include The PERMM Museum of Contemporary Art, The New Britain Museum of Art, The Moscow Museum of Modern Art (MMOMA), The Kemper Museum of Contemporary Art and the Smithsonian Institution to name a few.

Jansen also was selected as in the past Andy Warhol, Damien Hirst and Keith Haring as part of this generation of ABSOLUT VODKA's artists. He recently won three international Prizes in a row, the Arte Laguna Art Prize 2013, Venice Italy, The Dave Bown Projects Semi-Annual and the Aesthetica Art Prize in York, UK. Jansen's work is scheduled to show at Phillips de Pury International Auction London in 2014 and is represented by Galleria Bianca Maria Rizzi & Matthias Ritter in Milan Italy.

fields.title: UNIT A - Chronology
fields.content:
1968 


Born in Manhattan, New York, Jansen lived at 880 Boynton Ave. in the Bronx. During his first years in New York, he was raised in a predominantly West Indian and European area. His mother was a studying nurse from the West Indies, his Father an international businessman from Germany. Jansen is spoken to in English and German while growing up at home and grows up billingual.

1969

Jansen makes his first trip to Europe (including Germany and Belgium), Amsterdam, and Holland for summer vacation with his parents. They return to the US after a few weeks. Jansen's first overseas travel.

1970 

Jansen moves with his family ro Laurelton, Long Island, where he begins school in Queens NY. Soon after, his brother is born. 

1974

After a local school art competition, Jansen has his first painting selected to hang in the Lever House in Manhattan, which is known for its public support of the arts. The painting, of a lion, was completed by Jansen in an art class. This is the first time his work is displayed publicly.Jansen observes his first NYC Graffiti Subway cars passing by his neighborhood. 

1976

The family leaves New York and moves to Moenchengladbach, Germany. Jansen travels throughout Europe to France, Holland, Belgium, Switzerland, Italy, the UK, Luxembourg, and Spain. He observes and studies the European Masters of painting. Politics are at the forefront of conversations and discussions among the family: Jansen, however, rejects Politics at the time, and is more often found doodling on furniture and other household items instead. 

1982

On a trip back to New York, Jansen meets Graffiti legend WEST ONE through a family friend in Manhattan which prompts him to take a closer look at the Graffiti art that is now emerging as a world phenomenon. He is encouraged by WEST, who becomes somewhat of a mentor, to paint. He is picked up by the TV Talk Show host Daisy Dee. The two become friends.

1985

Jansen completes High School and continues his studies at the Berufsfachschule fuer Gestaltung/Design at the Berufskolleg Platz der Republik für Technik und Medien in Moenchengladbach, Germany at the request of his father. Jansen shows little interest his first year. He finds the class to be too regimented and decides to halt his studies.

1987

Like Willem de Kooning and many other European painters in the past that resided in Holland or Germany, Jansen continues a three year commercial Painting apprenticeship as a house painter. Jansen completes the apprenticeship, but has no interest in continuing with it as a profession. It is during this time that he becomes familiar with the usage of enamel paints. 

1990

Jansen decides to join the US Armed Forces from Germany and attends Military basic Training at Fort Leanardwood. He is assigned to Fort Bragg, North Carolina and serves with the 18th Airborne during Desert Storm as one of the first units deployed that August. Jansen spends nine months in the region. The tour takes a toll on Jansen.

1992

Jansen deploys to South Korea for one year and is stationed at the DMZ only 15 miles from the North Korean boarder. Jansen briefly meets Hillary Clinton during a visit at Camp Casey. He takes up boxing and serves as the company’s artist for painting jobs that are needed within the Battalion. During this time, Jansen stays isolated on Camp Casey during most of his assignment but makes close freinds with South Korean soldiers during training.

1993

Jansen returns from his South Korea tour and seeks assistance at the Walter Reed Hospital for Post Traumatic Stress from his Gulf War tour. Showing difficulties sleeping, Jansen spends time at the Hospital and attends Art Therapy classes, where he excels. He also meets Robert Suarez, a young soldier who later assists Jansen in establishing his art portfolio.

1995 

While later stationed at Fort Cambell, Kentucky, Jansen enrolls at Austin P. State University in Tennessee for leadership courses during his Primarily Leadership Development Course Academy. Jansen is shortly promoted to Sergeant after returning. He graduates his leadership course as one of the top soldiers in the class and attends Air Assault Training at Fort Bragg, NC.

1996

Jansen leaves his Military Intelligence Battalion at Aberdeen Proving Grounds in Washington: He does not do any painting during this time. He makes his second overseas tour to Germany and is stationed in Bavaria with the 1st Infantry Division in Vilseck. Jansen starts sketching while in Barracks headquarters, drawing promotional materials for events.. He meets his future wife Michaela in Aachen, Germany.

1997

Jansen discharges and opens an art studio in Aachen, Germany. He starts painting in a small studio to start his portfolio. Local Galleries reject his first works as immature and state that he cannot show because he does not have a name. He decides to show work at Street Art Fairs in Dortmund, Germany.

1999

Jansen decides to return to New York City and stands in SOHO between Prince Street and Broadway to test his work with a greater audience, next to the Victoria’s Secret building. He sells paintings alongside many artists, including artist Carlos Ramsey, for an average of $350 a piece. Many Hollywood celebrities, like John Ortiz. Ortiz buys Jansen's first work "Harlem Deli"while shooting a movie with Julian Schnabel. Ortiz promises Jansen to show Schnabel his work during the shooting. Jansen also has his first major group show at the Madison Square Garden Film & Art Festival. During this stay in NY, Jansen receives notice that his long time friend Robert Suarez dies in a tragic accident while in the Military. .

2000

The loss of his close friend takes a toll and Jansen returns to Germany, where he continues working in a small studio with the support of his wife Michaela from the former east Germany. He is invited to have his first two man show in Aachen at Kunsthandlung Schoenen with Marcel Schoenen. At the show, Jansen sells a 48x36" work to a German private collector for $5,000, Jansen's highest sale that year, which marks Jansen's work.

 2001

The Jansen's move to the United States and lives in Atlanta where he first shows with the Lagerquist Gallery and later with Bill Lowe Gallery. He is commissioned by Ford Motor Company for their 100th Anniversary in Dearborn Michigan. September 11th. strikes only three month's after his arrival and Jansen's art stands still for month's.

2003


Jansen moves to Southwest Florida after his first son is born and joins a stable of renowned painters who reside in the area Robert Rauschenberg, Roy Lichtenstein, and other internationally recognized painters. Jansen exhibits the pieces that were commissioned by the Ford Motor Company for the first time at the Charles H. Wright Museum. Jansen is asked to show in France by Jean-Marc Pontet. Pontet/Alphan, a dealer, art connoisseur, TV Director, and curator of the 1968 "de illuminations de Noel" at the l'avenue des Champ-Elysees in Paris. Alphan becomes Jansen's first dealer in France. Works are sold to largely French corporate and private collections.

2004 

Jansen is awarded the Angel of the Arts Award by the Alliance for the Arts in Fort Myers during the same year Robert Rauschenberg is awarded his lifetime achievement award. Jansen is introduced to Rauschenberg by musician Kat Epple for the first time at the Bob Rauschenberg Gallery during an art benefit showcase. Jansen has his first solo show in Paris, France at a solely committed Jansen Gallery at the American Art Gallery in the Le Merais art district. Later that year, Jansen meets Digital Artist Lawrence Gartel, as well as former Art Historian and Museum Director Jerome A. Donson. Both become mentors to the artist.

2005

Jansen shows at the Museum of African Art in a group show after friend Richard Baevers introduces Jansen's work to the Museum curator. He also has a solo exhibition in Paris at Art Au Garage called "Voice of a Generation". The Exhibition is broadcasted on LCI French TV and attracts French Art Auctioneer Pierre de Cornette de Saint Cyr to the opening. 

 2006

Jansen is selected to take part in the Florida State competition at the Tampa Museum of Art during under/current/over/view 8: the Juror is Jeffrey Grove, curator of Modern and Contemporary art at the High Museum of Art Atlanta. Mr. Crosby Kemper of The Kemper Museum of Contemporary Art purchases three of Jansen’s works. Kemper places two in the Museum's collection and one in his private collection. The Kemper Museum becomes the first Museum to purchase Jansen's work.

2007

For the first time, Jansen is Included in the 8th International Biennial St. Petersburg showing in Russia at the Central Manege Exhibition Hall: he has two works in the exhibition. One work is acquired by the Moscow Museum of Modern Art (MMOMA) permanent collection and he appears in Lowdown Magazine No. 54 Berlin Germany alongside artists like Ron English in four page feature. Later in the year, his print work of "Urban Times" is selected for the 12th International Print & Drawing Exhibition in Taiwan at the National Taiwan Museum of Fine Art. Jansen is one of two American Painters to be accepted. The Juror is David Kiehl from the Whitney Museum of American Art. The work is placed in the collection, and tours to the Kuandu Museum of Fine Arts and the Angel Art Gallery in Taiwan. Jansen starts showing at International Art Fairs during Art Basel Miami Beach and accepts new dealers Robert Casterline, with Museum Works Galleries and HW Gallery.

2008

The Stolen Space Gallery in London invites Jansen to do a solo show after Shepard Fairey’s large opening months prior. Jansen shows large works for the exhibition. Warner Brothers commissions Jansen the same year for their 80th anniversary during Art Basel Miami Beach after seeing Jansen's work at a solo opening at Lawrence Asher Gallery in Los Angeles previously that year. Soon after, he wins the "Aestehtica Magazine" Creative works competition. Jansen is also selected for the 22nd Juried Competition at the Visual Art Center in New Jersey. The Juror Curator and Curator of Drawings is Carter Foster, from the Whitney Museum of Art, New York. Jansen later appears on the cover with his 2008 work "foreclosures" in the "View from Now", on the "International Review of African American Art." Vol. 22, published by the Hamton University Museum.

 2009

The FIFA World cup commissions Jansen and shows his commissioned work at the International Convention Centre, Cape Town, South Africa, and the Deutsches Sport & Olympia Museum, Berlin, Germany. Jansen's dealer, Robert Casterline with Museum Works Gallery, make record sales and introduce his work to new private collectors. His work "Manufactured Landscapes" sets a new price for his large works at $35,000. 

2010

Art Pulse Magazine features a review on Jansen by Janet Batet. He is selected for the Texas 2010 National Competition at the Gwen Cole Art Center in Texas. The New Britain Museum of American Art acquires Jansen's "Patented Pig" for its permanent collection. In May, Jansen has his solo show, Zeitgeist, at 101 Exhibit. The exhibition draws his largest audience to date. Jansen is approached by ABSOLUT Vodka for commission: He joins the names of Andy Warhol, Keith Haring, and Damien Hirst. At the end of the 2010, the short Documentary “Marcus Jansen, A Painters Allegory” is filmed locally. It is the first intimate look into Jansen's studio. The filming is by Flip Minott, and Production by Eric Raddatz.

2011


After a fierce two year battle with cancer, Jansen's wife and longtime supporter Michaela dies tragically leaving behind two sons. Only two days after, Jansen creates new works and his ABSOLUT VODKA bottle for the ABSOLUT BLANK campaign. Later that year he is selected for the cover of New American Paintings No. 94 (curated by Dan Cameron, Founder of Prospect New Orleans), with his work "Creeping Obstacles in Kansas." He also shows at Art Hamptons, Art LA, Art Basel Miami Beach Scope, and other International Trade Fairs with 101 Exhibit. He is invited to show in the exhibition Florida Contemporaries at the Naples Museum of Art in Naples, alongside Michael Vasquez, Lydia Nelson, and others.  "Arts on Dekz", a Russel Simmons sponsored book project called "The Art Album", asks Jansen to participate in the upcoming year’s publication. He is featured with artists Shephard Fairey, Kehinde Wiley, Takashi Murakami, Marlene Dumas, Jonathan Meese, Daniel Richter, and more. 

2012

Art Historian and Museum Director Marat Guelman invites Jansen to be included at the PERMM Museum of Contemporary Art group show in "Anonymous": as a result, he places the work “Faceless # 2” in the permanent collection at the PERMM Museum. Jansen received an unrestricted monetary award of $10,000 from Dave Bown Projects as part of the 5th Semiannual Competition which was curated by Karl Hecksher, Owner of K5 Editions, New York; Andrea Karnes, Curator at the Modern Art Museum of Fort Worth; and Mary Kate O’Hare, Curator of American Art at the Newark Museum. Other International exhibitions include Art Platform L.A. and NOVA Festival de Cultura Contemporanea, Absolut Blank, Brazil. Jansen opens up his official studio Headquarters UNIT A.

2013

Is selected for the the Aesthetica Art Prize International award in the UK showing at York St. Mary's in York. In a collaboration with artist Jonas Stirner, "Robert Rauschenber's assistant" of fourteen years, the two host a show introducing Stirner's sculptures. Jansen is included in the The International Art Prize Arte Laguna 2013 – Venice Italy and shows at Romanian Institute for Arts Culture and Research, the Arsenale-Venice and the Maria Rizzi & Mathias Ritter Gallery in Milan Italy selects Jansen for his frst showing in Milan with official exhibition catalogue. Jansen is also featured at the Bob Rauschenberg Gallery in a curated group show called "Eye of the storm", by Dominic Lombardi, that travels to  The Housatonic Museum of Art, in Bridgeport,CT and is aqcuired for the permanent collection. Jansen also takes part in the Boca Raton Museum of Art curated exibition "All Florida"  by curator Mark Scala.

fields.title: UNIT A - Rentals
fields.content:
UNIT A - is the Headquarters open Studio  space for Artist Marcus Jansen's painting collection. The UNIT has over 7000sqft of urban loft studio space for business, music and other private functions. Email us through our contact page with inquiries.

Sonic Combine - An artistic night of sound, visuals & art presented by Marcus Jansen & Unit A. Mini Doc celebrating Cage, Cunningham, Mercer & Rauschenberg through Rauschenberg's close musician friends, Kat Epple, Lawrence Voytek & Lorrie Getford.

 

Urban Decaydence 2012. Private event by The Alliance for the Arts, curated by Pam Beckman.
